msg.data:
Setup

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Lab

msg.data: Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Find the Most Commonly Activated Devices Models

In this section, you will find the most common device models activated by counting model names and sorting by count. The count will be based on full aggregation of all the data received in the stream.

msg.data:
Find the Most Commonly Activated Devices Models

In this section, you will find the most common device models activated by counting
model names and sorting by count. The count will be based on full aggregation of all the
data received in the stream.

paragraphs.title: 1 - Terminate any Spark shells
paragraphs.text:
%md
If you currently have a Spark shell running in a terminal session, exit it.

paragraphs.title: 2 - Start a new local Spark shell
paragraphs.text:
%md
Start a new Python or Scala Spark shell running locally with two threads.

```
spark-shell --master local[2]
```

msg.data:
Start a new Python or Scala Spark shell running locally with two threads.

$ pyspark --master local[2]

$ spark-shell --master local[2]

paragraphs.title: 3 - Set the default number of partitions for shuffle operations
paragraphs.text:
%md
Set the default number of partitions for shuffle operations, which includes aggregation operations.

```
spark.conf.set("spark.sql.shuffle.partitions","4")
```

> The default number of partitions is 200. This is reasonable in a typical production cluster containing many worker hosts. Your exercise environment includes only a single host. If the number of partitions in a DataFrame greatly exceeds the number of worker hosts, you will get very poor performance. For these exercises, you must lower the number of partitions to allow your aggregation operations to complete in a reasonable amount of time.

msg.data:
Set the default number of partitions for shuffle operations, which includes
aggregation operations.

The default number of partitions is 200. This is reasonable in a
typical production cluster containing many worker hosts. Your
exercise environment includes only a single host. If the number of
partitions in a DataFrame greatly exceeds the number of worker
hosts, you will get very poor performance. For these exercises, you
must lower the number of partitions to allow your aggregation
operations to complete in a reasonable amount of time.

paragraphs.title: 4 - Create a streaming DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a streaming DataFrame called `kafkaDF` to receive messages in the `activations` topic.

```
val kafkaDF = spark.readStream.format("kafka").
option("kafka.bootstrap.servers", "localhost:9092").
option("subscribe", "activations").load
```

msg.data: Create a streaming DataFrame called kafkaDF to receive messages in the activations topic.

paragraphs.title: 5 - Create a new DataFrame based on kafkaDF
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a new DataFrame based on kafkaDF with an activation column containing the activation message values, parsed from JSON format.

```
import org.apache.spark.sql.types._

val activationsSchema = StructType( List(
StructField("acct_num", IntegerType),
StructField("dev_id", StringType),
StructField("phone", StringType),
StructField("model", StringType)))

val activationsDF = kafkaDF.
select(from_json($"value".cast("string"),
activationsSchema).alias("activation"))
```

msg.data:
Create a new DataFrame based on kafkaDF with an activation column
containing the activation message values, parsed from JSON format.

paragraphs.title: 6 - Create a streaming DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a streaming DataFrame that counts the rows in `activationsDF` by model name and sorts the results in descending order.

```
val sortedModelCountDF = activationsDF.
groupBy($"activation"("model")).count.
sort($"count".desc)
```

paragraphs.title: 7 - Start a query based on the sortedModelCountDF DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
The query should
- Display the complete results to the console
- Disable truncation of the rows
- Set a trigger interval of five seconds
    - This is not required by the query, but will aggregate larger batches of data so that you will be able to analyze the results more easily.

```
import org.apache.spark.sql.streaming.Trigger.ProcessingTime

val sortedModelCountQuery = sortedModelCountDF.
writeStream.outputMode("complete").format("console").
option("truncate","false").
trigger(ProcessingTime("5 seconds")).start
```

msg.data:
The query should

  • Display the complete results to the console
  • Disable truncation of the rows
  • Set a trigger interval of five seconds
    • This is not required by the query, but will aggregate larger batches of data so
      that you will be able to analyze the results more easily.

paragraphs.title: 8 - After starting the query, switch to a separate terminal session
9 - Create the activations topic for the streaming messages
paragraphs.text:
%md
(If you created it previously, you will get an exception saying the topic already exists. This is not aproblem and you can proceed with the exercises.)

```
kafka-topics --create --zookeeper localhost:2181 --partitions 2 --replication-factor 1 --topic activations
```

msg.data:
(If you created it previously, you will get an exception saying the topic already exists. This is not a
problem and you can proceed with the exercises.)

$ kafka-topics --create --zookeeper localhost:2181 \
--partitions 2 --replication-factor 1 --topic activations

paragraphs.title: 10 - Test the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
Generate Kafka messages to test the query using the provided test script.
```
/home/devuser/bin/devsh/scripts/streamtest-kafka.sh activations localhost:9092 10 /home/devuser/data/telco/activations_stream
```

msg.data:
Generate Kafka messages to test the query using the provided test script.

$ $DEVSH/scripts/streamtest-kafka.sh activations \
localhost:9092 10 $DEVDATA/activations_stream

paragraphs.title: 11 - Stopping the test script
paragraphs.text:
%md
Let the script run for about 20 seconds, then stop it using `Ctrl+C`.

msg.data: Let the script run for about 20 seconds, then stop it using Ctrl+C.

paragraphs.title: 12 - Observe the results
paragraphs.text:
%md
Return to the Spark shell and observe the results displayed on the console. Note that the model counts continue to increase between batches. They will increase indefinitely because the query runs against all the data received in the stream.

msg.data:
Return to the Spark shell and observe the results displayed on the console. Note
that the model counts continue to increase between batches. They will increase
indefinitely because the query runs against all the data received in the stream.

paragraphs.title: 13 - Stop the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
sortedModelCountQuery.stop
```

%md
### Count Activated Models within a Sliding Window

In this section, you will count the number of activation events per model every five seconds. Each batch of results will contain the counts for events received during the prior 10 seconds.

Note that aggregating results over a 10 second window would not be a common production use case. In the exercise, you will use this small window duration so that you can analyze the results more easily.

msg.data:
Count Activated Models within a Sliding Window

In this section, you will count the number of activation events per model every five
seconds. Each batch of results will contain the counts for events received during the
prior 10 seconds.

Note that aggregating results over a 10 second window would not be a common
production use case. In the exercise, you will use this small window duration so that
you can analyze the results more easily.

paragraphs.title: 14 - Create a DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a DataFrame called activationsTimeDF. This DataFrame will be identical to the activationsDF you created above, except that it will contain a timestamp column with the time the activation event occurred. An event time value is required to do aggregations within a window.

```
val activationsTimeDF = kafkaDF.
select($"timestamp",from_json($"value".cast("string"),
activationsSchema).alias("activation"))
```

paragraphs.title: 15 - Count activation events
paragraphs.text:
%md
Define a new DataFrame that counts activation events that occurred in the 10 seconds prior, updated every five seconds. In order to be able to analyze the query more easily, limit the query to models MeeToo 3.0 and 3.1.

```
val windowModelCountDF = activationsTimeDF.
where($"activation"("model").
startsWith("MeeToo 3")).
groupBy(window($"timestamp", "10 seconds", "5 seconds"),
$"activation"("model")).
count

msg.data:
Define a new DataFrame that counts activation events that occurred in the 10
seconds prior, updated every five seconds. In order to be able to analyze the query
more easily, limit the query to models MeeToo 3.0 and 3.1.

paragraphs.title: 16 - Start a query based on the windowModelCountDF DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
The query should

- Display the complete results to the console
- Disable truncation of the rows
- Set a trigger interval of five seconds

```
val windowModelCountQuery = windowModelCountDF.
writeStream.outputMode("complete").
format("console").option("truncate","false").
trigger(ProcessingTime("5 seconds")).start
```

msg.data:
The query should

  • Display the complete results to the console
  • Disable truncation of the rows
  • Set a trigger interval of five seconds

paragraphs.title: 17 - Test the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
In a separate terminal window, generate test events using the provided test script.

```
/home/devuser/bin/devsh/scripts/streamtest-kafka.sh activations localhost:9092 10 /home/devuser/data/telco/activations_stream
```

msg.data:
In a separate terminal window, generate test events using the provided test script.

$ $DEVSH/scripts/streamtest-kafka.sh activations \
localhost:9092 10 $DEVDATA/activations_stream

paragraphs.title: 18 - Stopping the test script
paragraphs.text:
%md
Let the script run for at least 20 seconds, then stop it using `Ctrl+C`.

msg.data: Let the script run for at least 20 seconds, then stop it using Ctrl+C.

paragraphs.title: 19 - Observe the results
paragraphs.text:
%md
Return to the Spark shell and observe the results displayed on the console.

In particular, take note of the time period values in the `window` column. The value is a pair consisting of a start time and an end time.

- Each period spans a 10-second time period, reflecting the window duration you specified above; for example, a period with start time `2019-06-05 08:12:40` and end time `2019-06-05 08:12:50`.
- New windows are generated every five seconds. For example, a period with start time `2019-06-05 08:12:40` will be followed by a period starting `2019-06-05 08:12:45` -- five seconds later.
- Each row in the results shows the number of times a particular device model occurred within a window. That means there will be up to two rows for any one window -- one with the MeeToo 3.0 count and the other with the MeeToo 3.1 count.
- The events included in consecutive windows overlap. That is, an event that occurred at `2019-06-05 08:12:48` is included in two 10-second windows: the `2019-06-05 08:12:40` and `2019-06-05 08:12:45` windows.
- Note that the results are unordered; results for consecutive windows may not be displayed consecutively in the output.

msg.data:
Return to the Spark shell and observe the results displayed on the console.

In particular, take note of the time period values in the window column. The value
is a pair consisting of a start time and an end time.

  • Each period spans a 10-second time period, reflecting the window duration you
    specified above; for example, a period with start time 2019-06-05 08:12:40
    and end time 2019-06-05 08:12:50.
  • New windows are generated every five seconds. For example, a period with
    start time 2019-06-05 08:12:40 will be followed by a period starting
    2019-06-05 08:12:45 – five seconds later.
  • Each row in the results shows the number of times a particular device model
    occurred within a window. That means there will be up to two rows for any one
    window – one with the MeeToo 3.0 count and the other with the MeeToo 3.1
    count.
  • The events included in consecutive windows overlap. That is, an event that
    occurred at 2019-06-05 08:12:48 is included in two 10-second windows:
    the 2019-06-05 08:12:40 and 2019-06-05 08:12:45 windows.
  • Note that the results are unordered; results for consecutive windows may not be
    displayed consecutively in the output.

paragraphs.title: 20 - Stop the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
windowModelCountQuery.stop
```

paragraphs.title: 21 - Run the query using the update output mode
paragraphs.text:
%md
Rerun the query above, except use the `update` output mode.

```
val windowModelCountQuery2 = windowModelCountDF.
writeStream.outputMode("update").
format("console").option("truncate","false").
trigger(processingTime="15 seconds").start()
```

Note that the trigger interval is longer than in the last query. This means that each batch will be based on more data, making the results easier to analyze.

msg.data:
Rerun the query above, except use the update output mode.

Note that the trigger interval is longer than in the last query. This means that each
batch will be based on more data, making the results easier to analyze.

paragraphs.title: 22 - Test the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
Generate test events as you did above. Let the script run for at least a minute.

```
/home/devuser/bin/devsh/scripts/streamtest-kafka.sh activations localhost:9092 10 /home/devuser/data/activations_stream
```

msg.data:
Generate test events as you did above. Let the script run for at least a minute.

$ $DEVSH/scripts/streamtest-kafka.sh activations \
localhost:9092 10 $DEVDATA/activations_stream

paragraphs.title: 23 - Review the output
paragraphs.text:
%md
Review the `update` mode output.

This time only windows with counts that changed between the previous batch and the current one are displayed. That is, if no MeeToo 3.0 devices were activated between `2019-06-05 08:12:40` and `2019-06-05 08:12:50`, then the row containing the MeeToo 3.0 count for that window will not be shown.

msg.data:
Review the update mode output.

This time only windows with counts that changed between the previous batch and
the current one are displayed. That is, if no MeeToo 3.0 devices were activated
between 2019-06-05 08:12:40 and 2019-06-05 08:12:50, then the row
containing the MeeToo 3.0 count for that window will not be shown.

paragraphs.title: 24 - Stopping the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
Stop the windowModelCountQuery2 query.

%md
### Join Streaming Activation and Static Account Data

In this section, you will join static account data in the `devsh.accounts` Hive table with streaming activation data based on the account ID. Only active accounts (those for which the `acct_close_dt` is null) will be included in the results. You will practice using both an inner and an outer join.

msg.data:
Join Streaming Activation and Static Account Data

In this section, you will join static account data in the devsh.accounts Hive table
with streaming activation data based on the account ID. Only active accounts (those for
which the acct_close_dt is null) will be included in the results. You will practice
using both an inner and an outer join.

paragraphs.title: 25 - Define a static DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
Define a static DataFrame containing rows where `acct_close_dt` is null.

```
val accountsStaticDF =
spark.read.table("telco.accounts")

val activeAccountsStaticDF = accountsStaticDf.
where($"acct_close_dt".isNull)
```

paragraphs.title: 26 - Join the DataFrames
paragraphs.text:
%md
Join the static active accounts DataFrame with the `activationsDF` you created in the previous section. Include the account number, first name, last name, account close date, and device ID in the new DataFrame.

```
val joinedDF = activeAccountsStaticDF.
join(activationsDF, activationsDF("activation")
("acct_num") ===
accountsStaticDF("acct_num")).
select("acct_num","first_name","last_name",
"acct_close_dt","activation.dev_id")
```

msg.data: Include the account number, first name, last name, account close date, and device ID in the new DataFrame.

paragraphs.title: 27 - Display account data
paragraphs.text:
%md
Start a query to display account data to the console. Use append output mode and set a one second trigger.

```
val joinedQuery = joinedDF.
writeStream.outputMode("append").
format("console").option("truncate","false").
trigger(ProcessingTime("1 seconds")).start
```

paragraphs.title: 28 - Test the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
Generate test events as you did in the last section. Let the script run for a few seconds.

msg.data:
??? Solution ???

$ $DEVSH/scripts/streamtest-kafka.sh activations \
localhost:9092 10 $DEVDATA/activations_stream

paragraphs.title: 29 - Review the output
paragraphs.text:
%md
Review the console output in the Spark shell. Note that the joined DataFrame contains only activation data associated with active accounts. Inactive accounts were excluded from the accounts data, and you performed an inner join (the default), so activation records for accounts not in the accounts DataFrame were ignored.

msg.data:
Review the console output in the Spark shell. Note that the joined DataFrame
contains only activation data associated with active accounts. Inactive accounts
were excluded from the accounts data, and you performed an inner join (the
default), so activation records for accounts not in the accounts DataFrame were
ignored.

paragraphs.title: 31 - Perform a right outer join
paragraphs.text:
%md
Repeat the steps above, but this time perform a right outer join.

```
val joinedRightDF = activeAccountsStaticDF.
join(activationsDF, activationsDF("activation")
("acct_num") ===
accountsStaticDF("acct_num"),"right_outer").
select("acct_num","first_name","last_name",
"acct_close_dt","activation.dev_id")

val joinedRightQuery = joinedRightDF.writeStream.
outputMode("append").format("console").
option("truncate","false").
trigger(ProcessingTime("1 seconds")).start
```

msg.data: Repeat the steps above, but this time perform a right outer join.

paragraphs.title: 32 - Test the query and compare the results
paragraphs.text:
%md
Test the query using the message generation script again and compare the results to the previous query. Note that this time, the output includes rows in which the account data (such as account number) is null. That is because the outer join includes all data from the streaming DataFrame, even when it does not have a matching row in the static DataFrame.

msg.data:
Test the query using the message generation script again and compare the results
to the previous query. Note that this time, the output includes rows in which the
account data (such as account number) is null. That is because the outer join
includes all data from the streaming DataFrame, even when it does not have a
matching row in the static DataFrame.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Find the Most Commonly Activated Devices Models

paragraphs.title: 2 - Start a new local Spark shell
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
spark-shell --master local[2]
```

paragraphs.title: 3 - Set the default number of partitions for shuffle operations
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
spark.conf.set("spark.sql.shuffle.partitions","4")
```

paragraphs.title: 4 - Create a streaming DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
val kafkaDF = spark.readStream.format("kafka").option("kafka.bootstrap.servers", "localhost:9092").option("subscribe", "activations").load
```

paragraphs.title: 5 - Create a new DataFrame based on kafkaDF
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
import org.apache.spark.sql.types._
val activationsSchema = StructType( List(
  StructField("acct_num", IntegerType),
  StructField("dev_id", StringType),
  StructField("phone", StringType),
  StructField("model", StringType))) 

val activationsDF = kafkaDF.select(from_json($"value".cast("string"), activationsSchema).alias("activation"))
```

paragraphs.title: 6 - Create a streaming DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
val sortedModelCountDF = activationsDF.groupBy($"activation"("model")).count.sort($"count".desc)
```

paragraphs.title: 7 - Start a query based on the sortedModelCountDF DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
import org.apache.spark.sql.streaming.Trigger.ProcessingTime
val sortedModelCountQuery = sortedModelCountDF.writeStream.outputMode("complete").format("console").option("truncate","false").trigger(ProcessingTime("5 seconds")).start
```

paragraphs.title: 8 - After starting the query, switch to a separate terminal session
9 - Create the activations topic for the streaming session
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
kafka-topics --create --zookeeper localhost:2181 --partitions 2 --replication-factor 1 --topic activations
```

paragraphs.title: 10 - Test the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
/home/devuser/bin/devsh/scripts/streamtest-kafka.sh activations localhost:9092 10 /home/devuser/data/telco/activations_stream
```

paragraphs.title: 11 - Stopping the test script
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
Ctrl+C
```

paragraphs.title: 13 - Stop the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
sortedModelCountQuery.stop
```

%md
### Count Activated Models within a Sliding Window

msg.data: Count Activated Models within a Sliding Window

paragraphs.title: 14 - Create a DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
val activationsTimeDF = kafkaDF.select($"timestamp",from_json($"value".cast("string"), activationsSchema).alias("activation"))
```

paragraphs.title: 15 - Count activation events
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
val windowModelCountDF = activationsTimeDF.where($"activation"("model").startsWith("MeeToo 3")).groupBy(window($"timestamp", "10 seconds", "5 seconds"), $"activation"("model")).count
```

paragraphs.title: 16 - Start a query based on the windowModelCountDF DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
val windowModelCountQuery = windowModelCountDF.writeStream.outputMode("complete").format("console").option("truncate","false").trigger(ProcessingTime("5 seconds")).start
```

paragraphs.title: 17 - Test the query

```

```

```
Ctrl+C
```

```

```

paragraphs.title: 21 - Run the query using the update output mode
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
val windowModelCountQuery2 = windowModelCountDF.writeStream.outputMode("update").format("console").option("truncate","false").trigger(ProcessingTime("15 seconds")).start
```

paragraphs.title: 22 - Test the query
paragraphs.text:

```
/home/devuser/bin/devsh/scripts/streamtest-kafka.sh activations localhost:9092 10 /home/devuser/data/activations_stream

%md
### Join Streaming Activation and Static Account Data

msg.data: Join Streaming Activation and Static Account Data

paragraphs.title: 25 - Define a static DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
val accountsStaticDF = spark.read.table("telco.accounts")

val activeAccountsStaticDF = accountsStaticDF.where($"acct_close_dt".isNull)
```

paragraphs.title: 26 - Join the DataFrames
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
val joinedDF = activeAccountsStaticDF.join(activationsDF, activationsDF("activation")("acct_num") === accountsStaticDF("acct_num")).select("acct_num","first_name","last_name","acct_close_dt","activation.dev_id")
```

paragraphs.title: 27 - Display account data
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
val joinedQuery = joinedDF.writeStream.outputMode("append").format("console").option("truncate","false").trigger(ProcessingTime("1 seconds")).start
```

paragraphs.title: 28 - Test the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
/home/devuser/bin/devsh/scripts/streamtest-kafka.sh activations localhost:9092 10 /home/devuser/data/telco/activations_stream
```

paragraphs.title: 30 - Stop the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
joinedQuery.stop
```

paragraphs.title: 31 - Perform a right outer join
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
val joinedRightDF = activeAccountsStaticDF.join(activationsDF, activationsDF("activation")("acct_num") === accountsStaticDF("acct_num"),"right_outer").select("acct_num","first_name","last_name","acct_close_dt","activation.dev_id")

val joinedRightQuery = joinedRightDF.writeStream.outputMode("append").format("console").option("truncate","false").trigger(ProcessingTime("1 seconds")).start

paragraphs.title: 32 - Test the query and review the results
33 - Stop the query
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
joinedRightQuery.stop
```
